reviewText: I have been a transformers fan since I was a little kid and now both of my sons are getting into it.  I have been looking and spending countless days waiting for good deals on Amazon.com and when this came up I could not pass it up.  Pre-order and get it at a lower price with free 2 day shipping, again great!!  It was received the day it said it was going to be here and with all of the emails telling me when it was shipped and when I shopuld expect it, great service on all parts starting from check out to receiving.  My sons and I opened this box set, Transformers Victory, the day it arrived, finished their homework of course, and watched it from beginning to end (not all in one day).  We did not care that it was sub-titled, my sons just kept asking what they were saying and it was absolutely fine with me. This is one of those timeless classics that never gets old (i.e. the Original Star Wars Trilogy, not the added scene stuff G. Lucas keeps putting out to get more money).  Love watching the old G1 cartoons and so are both of my boys.

reviewText: This is a phenomenal conclusion to the original Transformers through the Japanese collection cycle. I highly recommend this to all fans of the Transformers, its action, and stories are, like Headmasters and Masterforce, totally worth the experience. Even with Subtitles needing to be read, the stories and action is a worthy addition to the Transformers universe.

reviewText: Masterforce, despite some of it's shortcomings, delivered a fairly solid story, and the chief writer, Masumi Kaneda, wrote an outline for Victory as well, and would go on to write the associated manga version of the story. Comparing the manga to the anime presented here gives you a good idea of just how few of those ideas actually got used in the TV series. I'm not going to go on about the manga any further but let's just say that it is, even in it's rather bizarre story elements, a far superior version of the story compared to this thing.After Masterforce's rather unusual elements which no doubt turned off a lot of oldschool fans, Victory returns to the basics; Decepticons want to steal energy and Autobots have to stop them. Which is all nice and dandy, but in terms of actual story, that's pretty much all there is to it. Sure, the Decepticons have a different reason for doing it this time around, but Victory has absolutely none of the character of the classic American Transformers cartoon. Remember when the old series would often break out of form with more unconventional stories, like Wheeljack coming up with some new invention, Decepticons trying to rebuild earth into a new Cybertron or stealing cars to turn them into transforming drones? Or Spike and Optimus Prime playing basketball against the Dinobots? Yeah, there's absolutely nothing like that here. Almost every episode begins with the Decepticons coming up with some new plan and all the Autobots do is react to it. And speaking of the Autobots, Star Saber is the most uncharismatic Autobot leader I have ever seen. Optimus Prime sometimes gets flak for being a flawless, father-figure leader, but he still demonstrated some kind of personality quirks that gave the character some warmth, like performing tricks with the aforementioned basketball while idling. Star Saber has absolutely none of that. He has an adoptive son, but their relationship is incredibly formal. There's never any kind of conflict between them. In fact, there's barely any conflict between the Autobots period. Sure, there's that one veteran Autobot who acts like a condescending jerk towards the rookie, but that's just another anime cliche. The Autobots are horrifically lacking in any sort of personality with a stiff, military-like formality in their interactions that would even make them likeable, let alone relatable - and the worst part is that because of this, the Decepticons come off as the far more likeable faction solely for having no less than TWO Starscream-type characters!And what about the story? About half of the entire series consists of just the Decepticons attacking someplace to steal energy and the Autobots show up to stop them. That's it. There are no twists. It's so ridicilously formulaic it makes the original American show look like Dallas. Fortunately, the series picks up when everyone heads off to planet Micro, the home planet of the diminutive Micromastes, and we start getting more interesting plot devices like metal-eating insects, but ultimately those too fall to the form of  "Decepticons act, Autobots react".Actually, the best way to describe Victory is by saying it's like stylistic suck, if you pardon my TV tropes terminology here. Ever watched a cartoon character watch a cartoon, and it's a ridicilous, cliche-riddled oneliner-spewing trite, like the stereotypical adult's view of an action cartoon for kids? That's pretty much Victory in a nutshell. It really, really, really is not the kind of show you'd want to intake in more than small chunks at best.
summary: Talk about going out with a whistle

But anyway Now that I have Masterforce and Victory, now all I need to get is the Headmasters boxset. Also why couldn't Shout Factory release Transformers Zone, Beast Wars Second and Beast Wars Neo. Here in the United States yet? We're still waiting Shout Factory, come on with it already!!!!
